Songs created here are saved as text files on your internal storage.
The default app folder is called sheets. 

Tip:
 Sync that folder with an app like FolderSync to Google Drive/Dropbox to be able to edit your sheets with a real keyboard on your laptop.

Concept

The general idea of this app is to save your leadsheets as text files. This is a use case that might resonate with you if you tend to see leadsheets not as an accurate note-by-note transcriptions of a given music piece but rather as a terse abstract which only contains the crucial, harder to remember parts.

You can take a look at my collection of sheets to get an idea what I am talking about: https://github.com/jonathanewerner/sheets?files=1

I also encourage you to check out the Nashville Number System, which I employ most of the time, as it really makes it feasible to write leadsheets on your cellphone and allows you to transpose any song to every possible key with ease, on the fly.

Projects

Projects are simply folders saved under the root folder of the app (which is sheets by default). They contain songs, which you can order in a setlist. If you need a song in two different projects just copy the file (right now you would have to do this with an external file manager - i found Solid Explorer to be quite pleasant) - this way changes in a song are always project-specific.

Setlists

This app deliberately makes the assumption of only one setlist at a given point in time per project in order to decrease the complexity of the app.

You can also get a Library view of your projects songs by clicking the icon in the upper right. This might come in handy during rehearsals when you have to access all of the songs alphabetically sorted.

One important non-obvious point: if you delete songs (either by swiping them right or invoking the context menu long-pressing on them), they are not deleted on the filesystem, but rather moved into an .archive-folder, so that you can restore them in case the deletion wasn\'t intentional.
